content.description:
Fun movement on good crimps. Good shoulder move. I just did this yesterday.

Justin Keener showed me this one - thanks for always having so much vision in this canyon, man.

Update May 2020: looks like other people are climbing this, and enjoying it! Great!
content.location: Start left hand on the left hand start hold of Cynthia's. Start right hand on the weird indented slot crimp of Head On, then gaston left hand to the crimp, then jump to the rail and finish.

content.description: On the NW corner, between two small boulders, Mini-Bulge starts as a sit start on jugs.  Reach over and through the bulge on jugs.  Finish with a fun mantle.
content.location: NW corner of Cynthia's Boulder.  Between two boulders, on the right.

content.description:
Awesome 2 move problem on perfect stone. Really cool grips on this one, and great movement between.

Start with a left hand thin three finger crimp, and right hand slopey pinch, with feet on the big rail below. Power up to the rail, and finish on the eliminator.
content.location: See description above. This is a low sit start to the Eliminator.

content.description:
Start almost the same as Minch, but use a better higher wider left hand (right hand on a slopey sidepull notch).

Do one hard move up to the positive lip, and finish the easy top out

about as hard as Cynthia’s V4 on the other end of the boulder
content.location: W side of the N face, just left of the tree

content.description:
Spectacular movement on subtle, solid holds on a cool overhanging arete capped by an awesome technical dead point. Rock feels like Tiger Snake or Blindside. It is the best boulder in this main area.

Most people seem to start matched on the juggy brick, or with left hand on the pinch and right hand on the brick. For added difficulty, there are two more holds to the left, and if you start over there and climb into the brick, bonus points. :)

There are two variations for the crux (at least)

If you stay high, it is satisfyingly stiff for v9. I've heard a couple people say it could be in the solid 10 territory using the high approach.

If you stay low, you better be tall. I have a 6 foot span, and I can only barely reach between those low holds. The taller you are, the easier that low method is likely to feel.

Inaccurately given grade of v6 in the black. I talked to Mike Beck about it, and he says that that was a shot in the dark, not based on experience. Thanks Mike.

Old school classic!
content.location: Pass the slightly overhanging crimp covered face, and pass into a corridor with some trees. Start sitting quite low on the left side of the left overhanging arete, hanging from the lowest  flake that you can lay down into, then power up and right through a series of cool holds, and finish out on the face and up over the top.

content.description: Great movement on edges up the middle of the face. Perhaps the most obvious problem on the boulder. Very good movement.
content.location: Start sitting in the middle of the face, a few feet right of Cynthia's problem. Right hand starts on a pinchy edge thing, and left hand on a slopey edge with a thumb catch, work up slightly left and top out above.

content.description: A fun linkup of Head-on and Cynthia's. Start as for Head-on and do the first move, now right-hand moves to sloper edge in the middle of the wall and left moves to a gaston ( the right hand on Cynthia's problem). Fun right-hand move to the lip and mantle.
content.location: On the Middle of Cynthia's boulder

content.description: Adds an awesome sit start into the Eliminator Variation making EV a bit more full value.
content.location:
Start with left hand on the pinch edge rounded thing, and right hand on a toothy edge. Power left hand up to the left start hold of the stand start, and then into the good edge of the right hand stand start hold. Finish on Eliminator Variation, not using the Eliminator holds on the right.

All this description would have been much easier if Eliminator had been named something else.

content.description:
Things start to get a little complicated with what is what on this boulder, but all the lines have value. This climb is confusingly called Eliminator variation, but you don't use any of the holds on the Eliminator itself.

Start low with a thin left hand crimp and a right hand on a good big edge, power up and left into a groove and top out above. Good movement.
content.location: As above, use starting holds down and left of Eliminator, work up and left.

content.description: Start with a jug at mid height.  Pull through on good jugs to an awkward mantle finish.
content.location: Behind the pine tree on the north face.

content.description: A Lip traverse, this variation starts on the left side of the north face.  It attains the lip and then hand traverses right until you can gain the slot by the pine tree.  A good problem with reaches to slopers.
content.location: North Face of Cynthia's Boulder.  Start left.

content.description: A one mover that is worth doing. Namesake of the boulder.
content.location: Start left hand on the low side pull crimp, and right hand on the high right diagonal side pull crimp on the face. One move to the top and top out.
